title: Ikea JANSJÖ LED Lamp - Color Gel Holder and Wall Mount

description.text:
The JANSJÖ lamp is a great, cheap little 2w LED lamp, great for lighting various things like artwork, work bench, etc.

http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/20169658/

This is a clip on color film/gel holder for changing the color of the lamp (the old fashion way). I use them for lighting artwork/sculptures with color light. Comes in 2 pieces, the clip on frame and the face plate, the face plate is to meant to be super glued on to the base clip on frame, you can use an little M2 screw to keep the gel from slipping out.

Also included here is a little hard mount bracket for the lamp itself, for permanent mounting of the lamp.

Example plastic film/gel material:
https://www.amazon.com/Neewer-12-Inches-Transparent-Correction-Different/dp/B01CCIKB5Q/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1508729798&sr=8-2&keywords=color+film+gel

Print with no support. Works with ABS or PLA, I advise ABS as it has better heat resistance than PLA, but the lamp doesn't get that hot, so not really an issue.

description.text:
I was looking for an airplane puzzle I could make both on my DIY CNC Router and print on my Robo 3D. I found this design of a generic Biplane. It wasn't until many hours (of recreating this airplane) later that I discovered someone had already uploaded a similar file. Note: This is not a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2411381

After creating the initial layout, I took the liberty of modifying my sketched design to suit my liking. I also doubled-up the thickness of the main landing gear wheels to lend a better look.

Files are uploaded for the CNC,3D Printer, and Laser versions. For the CNC and Laser versions, remember to tweak the design for your material thickness and cutter diameter to get a nice fit.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 um

Infill:

30%

Notes:

There are no special requirements to print these parts.

For the 3D Printer version, I recommend letting the parts cool completely to avoid distortion. Parts slide together with little effort. As with any puzzle, there is a certain order to assemble the parts to build the plane.

For the CNC version, cut the parts loose from the their tabs, and sand as needed. Due to the size of the Wheel Retainers, that hold on the Wheels, there is no corner relief. You can either sand or file a square corner on each side of the retainers or chamfer the edges of wheel's inside diameter for clearance.

This was designed by tracing a PDF drawing of a Brazilian 3D Puzzle of a generic Biplane.
The initial layout work was done in AutoCAD. For a 3D view, I modeled this in Pro/E to create the STL files. I wanted to be able to 3D print this plane and cut it out on my CNC Router. The the Router files have all the cut-outs and corner reliefs defined for a 1/8" diameter bit.

The material for the wooden plane was purchased from Hobby Lobby and came in a package of three 10" diameter by 1/8" thick pieces of plywood.

title: Babylon Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Babylon is a simple and fast-playing brain teaser for two players.
The game consists of twelve tiles in four colors, and the tiles are scattered on the table at the start of play, creating twelve stacks that are each one tile high. On a turn, you take one stack and place it on another stack that is either (a) the same height or (b) topped by a tile of the same color. Stacks cannot be divided.
12 sculptured stone pieces (3 Green, 3 Black, 3 Red, 3 Beige),
I have provided 2 variations for pieces

description.text:
I always use these things off-camera, so I don't need the hotshoe foot, which requires yet another adapter to mount on a light stand. This is a replacement for the hotshoe foot with an embedded 1/4-20 nut so you can directly screw it to your softbox or umbrella mount, light stand, clamp, tripod, spigot, etc.

Just unscrew the four screws, carefully remove the tiny plug inside, pop in the printed part (see below for minor post-processing work) and attach with the same screws (don't over-tighten the small screws or you might strip the threads).

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print upright with a brim for bed adhesion. Make sure your tolerances and material shrinkage is dialed in well.

Use a tough plastic like nylon - I used HIPS and it's super sturdy, but your mileage my vary.

Use an exacto knive and sand paper to remove the brim and if necessary make it fit the case without pressing the to halves apart (watch the seams of the case).

Press-fit the 1/4-20 nut - I used hot-glue to be sure. Then cover the end of the nut with some painters tape to avoid dust coming into the flash and to make sure there is no exposed conductor on the inside.

Attach it with the four screws.

author: Anubis_

description.text:
This is a scoreboard I made for Ultimate frisbee (we don't usually play to higher than 17 points). this would be good for any other similar scoring sports, or easily adapted to higher scores.

I used a thing piece of plywood as the backing, painted white. I drew the lines on with sharpie, and traced the letters from printouts. I also made a printout for the digits, based on the file full segments.stl, to make sure the spacing was correct.

I used nylon cord (Dritz 9342B to be specific, I used just over 1 package worth, but if you're careful you might be able to get by with just one.) to hold the pieces to the board. It's very easy to flip the pieces over.

Each piece is one white segment.stl and one black segment.stl superglued together with the hole in the middle.

Once the board was made, I made a tripod holder for it out with three 2x2s. The scoreboard is roughly 2 feet wide.

Overall a very easy project.

10%

title: Mount for E3D V6, Blower, and BLTouch

description.text:
This is a simple mount for an E3D V6 hot end with a blower on the left side and BLTouch on the right. It includes a blower duct and shim for the BLTouch. It is designed to use a brass insert (M3 5mmx5mm) to attach the blower to the mount. The X,Y,Z offsets for this mount are, respectively: 39, 4, -2.3.

NOTE: The current iteration has the tip of the BLTouch probe offset about 40mm from the tip of the extruder. If this proves to be an issue in testing I'll modify the design to move it a bit closer.

EDIT (10/23/2017): Uploaded a new version of the back and front pieces to adjust the position of the hotend a bit so that it lines up better with the filament coming out of the MK8/MK9 extruder.

EDIT (11/07/2017): I added files for a second version (back/front/shim_v2) that puts the probe a little closer to the nozzle. By using a slight negative X endstop position (-14mm on my setup) and a 10mm UBL margin it's now able to completely probe the bed automatically. The X,Y,Z offsets for this mount are, respectively: 25, -2, -2.3.

Printer:

FolgerTech i3 2020

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Parts shown were printed with Atomic Filaments carbon fiber PETG.

title: Raspberry Pi Octoprint Printer Server Stand V2

description.text:
This is a remix from Adafruit's Octoprint.

I was not happy how the Pi case was sitting loose on the stand. Designed a solution of the case and stand so it would be more stable on the stand. Also redesigned the stand to be able to have better cable management for the cables to the Pi.

There are two versions of the top part of the Pi case included:

  • one is with the server text for Multi Material Upgrades or dual extruders.
  • the other version is a plain one without the text.

I printed the stand in 0.35 resolution as I did not think a higher resolution was necessary.

Prusa

i3 MK2 MMU

Rafts:

No

description.text:
The FilaWinder BBSpool Adaptors allow for spools with larger centers holes to be used.
With the BBSpool Adaptors you can now use spools with center hole openings up to 89mm.

The FilaWinder comes with spool hubs that allow spools with center opening holes of a max of 55mm. You can use the standard hubs on holes up to 59mm but the spool then catches on the drive gear and control board pins so not ideal.

Print 2 of them. They simply click in and can be pulled off when using smaller spools.

Printed upside down with supports only due to my bed having current poor adhesion. It might be possible to print normally without support. I used 60% infil to ensure if it was rigid.

I printed the parts in ABS but nothing stopping the use of PLA or others.

Hopefully this helps some people out as I could not see anything out there to help get around this issue.

sort of working model of an old portable sundial

The "all" file is and assemble stl it is not meant to be printed but is there for you to see what the assemble sundial looks like. print out 1 each of outerring innerring bridge and hanger 2 copies of peephole and 3 copies of pivot. the hanger should snap onto the outside of the outer ring.
put the inner ring inside the outerring with the pivot holes lined up push two of the pivots into the holes in the inner ring they should push through and into the holes in the outer ring allowing the in ring to swing out 90 degrees before it hits the stops. Push the remaining pivot into the hole in the end of the bridge until it is flush, fit the end with the built in pivot into the hole on one of the supports on the outer ring you should be able to use a small screwdriver or similar tool to push the pivot you fitted to the bridge into the hole in the other support. final part of the assembly is to fit the two peephole parts these should push together with so they fit into the bridge and slide up and down. there are marks on the outer ring every 5 degrees and 24 marks round the iner ring I was not able to produce readable engraving on these two pieces. the bridge has letters corresponding to the months of the year. To read the dial first set it for you latitude by moving the hanger round the outer ring 90 degrees ( the north pole) would be with the hanger in line with the brige and 0 degrees ( the equator) would be with the haner lined up with the pivots on the inner ring. move the peephole until the letter corresponding to the month is covered. hang the dial by the hanger you will need to twist the bridge and turn the hole dial until the sun shines through the peephole and hits the inside of the inner ring (there is a indented line on the inerring to help get it central) then count of the tine on the inter ring 6 O'clock would be at the point the ring pivots (both morning and evening) midday is at right angles to this. I have found I could get the time to within about half an hour with practice. Edit changed the oriatation of the peephole file to make printing easer. edit run all the file through Netfabb since some people reported problems slicesing the parts

title: Lizard95 Nylon Frame (nearly indestructible)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Print in Nylon 910 Alloy Filament. Dry the filament for about 2-3h in the oven (100°C) before printing. After the frame is printed the filament will get flexible again within 2 days.(absorbs water from the air). A good indicator if the print is good is that the material neraly looks clear. When it looks like white the reason are microbubbles due to too much wuter in the filament. This will weaken the strenght of the material! It should loke like in the last picture.

Attention: You have to change the PID setting because the frame is very flexible.
They work for the beginning:

set p_pitch = 32
set i_pitch = 28
set d_pitch = 5
set p_roll = 32
set i_roll = 28
set d_roll = 5
set p_yaw = 30
set i_yaw = 20
set d_yaw = 5

The Tower gehts mountet by just pressing it in. You dont need the screws saving weight. If the tower won't fit at the first time you can heat up every edge after the oter and widen it a bit.

For the battery Mount: 2mm carbon/metal rod with an o-ring(30mm/2mm) and velcro-->bulletproof

description.text:
3D Printed Magnetic Paddle Shifter

These 3D printed magnetic paddle shifters are designed for sim racing with an OSW direct drive wheel.
The shifters should be compatible with other wheels as well but you may need to build a custom mounting plate.

Please note, the button plate is posted as a seperate project on Thingiverse. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2601312

The shifters are part of the Open Source Button Box project and have been tested with the project's "Wheel Button Box".

Please check the following video for details
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CnJ3shNiE3g

Full source files are availble on the project's Github page
https://github.com/KaiserSoft/OpenSimButtonBox/tree/master/Magnetic%20Paddle%20Shifters

Notes:

Assembly Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kEENwVqYf5s

Bill of Materials

The following parts are required to assemble one shifter unit. Each shifter requires on micro switch. The type depends on which Body you are printing.

  • 2x 623ZZ ball bearing
  • 1x M3x45mm flat head machine screw
  • 1x M3 nut / locking nut for machine screw
  • 2x 12x3mm neodymium magnet (round disk shape).
    You may order additional magnets to adjust the force required. I recommend at least one more 12x2mm
  • 2x M3x12mm counter sunk screw for mounting the paddles to the shift lever
  • 2x M3 nut for the M3x12mm counter sunk screw
  • 2x M3 countersunk screw for mounting the unit to your button box or wheel
  • 1x Omron D2F-01 or D2F-01-D3 micro switch or cheap clones D2FC-F-7N on ebay

title: Jack-O-Lantern Candy Dispenser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Jack-O-Lantern Candy Dispenser is a fun way to dispense candy over the Halloween period.

The design features and internal structure that rotates to open / close a hatch in the mouth. It's easy to use... with the mouth hatch closed just pour candy into the hole in the top of the stem then rotate the stem to open the hatch and dispense candy out through the mouth.

At standard scale the dispenser will take candy up to approx. 15mm in diameter. Scale up uniformly to dispense larger pieces. Scaling down is not recommended as it will reduce the internal clearances which may result in the moving surfaces to fuse so the dispenser will not rotate to open / close.

This is an easy print but it is large and will take quite a while to print... but it's well worth the time / effort / cost. At standard scale the dispenser is approx. 110mm round and 88mm high including the stem. It will hold a surprisingly large amount of small pieces of candy... and can be used for years to come. Looks great in traditional pumpkin orange or any other color.

Do not use any automated support. The required support has been designed in and should snap away easily (Refer to the images for additional details). More than usual clearance has been designed in so the internal part should rotate free straight off the build plate. However, if it has fused slightly it is most likely the base shaft area so use a craft knife to gently break it free to turn.

Please refer to the print instructions and images for additional information... and post images of your Jack-O-Lantern Candy Dispenser in use for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 10% infill

Notes:

Straight forward print but it will use approx. 140gm filament at standard scale (with a raft).

Good build plate adhesion is essential to ensure the parts do not move during printing as this could cause them to fuse (...and not rotate to open / close the mouth hatch).

Do not use any automated support. The designed in support should break away cleanly by hand after printing.

A well sliced file printed on a well set up / precise machine should result in a Jack-O-Lantern Candy Dispenser that rotates and is ready to use straight off the build plate.

Just remove the designed in support, check the stem rotates freely and fill with candy!

A well printed dispenser should be ready for use within minutes of the print being completed. Just snap away the small amount of designed in support (at the mouth) then check the stem rotates freely. If not, gently use a craft knife to break the base shaft free.

Make sure the hatch is closed then fill with candy... have fun with it!

description.text: These small clips mount on the diagonal front piece of the Replicator Hood by Dave Randolf: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23386 I love this hood, but one of the minor annoying things was that the sloped piece on the front sagged a little bit, since it was unsupported except at the edges. These clips join the sloped piece to the top and front at a couple of points, fixing the sag and any vibration of that piece. In addition, the lower clips have an extra slot, that can be used to hold the front cover out of the way when it is removed. I was really surprised that this improves the rigidity of the hood dramatically. It's a must-do if you have one of Dave's hoods.

Nothing special to print.  
The major issue is that you have to remove one of the sides of the hood to slip the clips in.  If you assembled the hood, you probably know enough to tape the nuts in place before removing the side.  
Note that the clips only logically fit in place one way, the hood edges won't match if you try to place them in backwards.  The lower edge clips are obvious since they have the extra slot to hold the front cover.

comments.text: Initially printed at 20% fill.  They came out as hollow walls.  Revised to 100% fill, 0 extra walls.  Much better.  They went on a little loosely though, but that could just be my acrylic.  Otherwise they act as advertised and removed the sag in my angled panel.

comments.text: These made a MASSIVE difference in the rigidity of the hood.   I very highly recommend them!

OSW Button Plate - DIY Direct Drive Wheel Button Plate

The button plate is designed to be compatible with a 320mm Beltenick steering wheel. It should be compatible to similar wheel with Sparko/Momo drill pattern.
https://www.rennsportshop.com/de-fahrzeug-technik-lenkraeder-lenkradzubehoer-beltenick-rmd-qualitaetslenkraeder-BK-LR32000-Beltenick-Lenkrad-Racing-320mm.html

This project is part of the Open Sim Button Box Project. Full source files and description may be found at the project's GitHub page
https://github.com/KaiserSoft/OpenSimButtonBox/tree/master/Wheel%20Button%20Box

The plate is comatible to the Magnetic Paddle Shifter I have posted here as well.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2601233

Demonstration Videos
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CnJ3shNiE3g
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k06J8A-eg9A

Printer:

MendelMax 1.5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25% to 30%

Required Parts
  • Arduino Pro Micro 16MHz - Will not work with most other Arduinos since they can not act as a HID. Teensy should work as well but it is more expensive.
  • 10x push buttons with a thread diameter of around 12mm. The kind with a metal body works as well but they are heavier.
  • 1x Arduino Joystick Module - pay close attention to the circuit board since there are different types and the button box only works when the dimensions are correct.
  • Coiled Micro USB Cable - this connects the button box to your PC. It needs to be coiled so it can flex all the way to the end stops.

Build Instructions
  • Print the button box and do basic cleanup. Rough up the sides where the box is split and use glue to join the two halves back together. You don't need much glue since this only makes it easier to install the buttons and cables. The button box will be held in place by the screws connecting the wheel to the mounting hub on the OSW motor.
  • Install the buttons and solder the wires in place. Cut the wires long enough so that they can exit the arduino box at the bottom.
  • Desolder the connection pin header on your joystick module.
  • Solder wires to the joystick module and run them to the arduino box as well
  • Ensure that every button is working by using the continuity test setting on your multi meter
  • Ensure the joystick is working by testing the resistance
  • Add wires for the magnetic paddle shifters as well. I recommend that you don't connect the sifters yet. Simply run wires and solder them to the paddle shifter wires once you are ready to assemble it all.
  • Connect all wires as described in "CONFIG.h". Buttons use the "Button_X_Pin" and the joystick the "Joystick_X_Pin" setting.
  • Remove some of the plastic on the outside of the micro USB connector. This makes the connector shorter and makes in easier to push it through the hole inside the button box.
  • Connect the coiled USB cable to the arduino and upload the scetch to the board
  • Test every button and joystick
  • Test the buttons again
  • Push the arduino into the arduino box at the bottom. Pull extra wires into the button box body and hide them in the wire channel.
  • Test the buttons again
  • Fill the arduino box with hot glue or silicone sealant. This ensures that the micro USB connector will not disconnect and that the arduino will not move
  • Run the rest of the USB cable through wire channel at the bottom of the unit
  • Assemble everything and connect the padde shifters
  • Mount everything to the OSW and attach the wheel
  • All done. You can use the arduino software to change which button sends which command (CONFIG.h file)
  • Have fun!

author: diarx

description.text:
Background

Some time ago I decided to build a new project, and picked the DrawingBot by MakerC (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1517211). A bit of research also picked out the remixes by avanhanegem (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2058866) and henryarnold (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2349232) - their excellent ideas, designs and other contributions have all been considered in this re-design.

After looking at the original designs l decided that I wanted to make some changes - mostly to the idler pulleys and GT2 belt fixing, but also to tidy up a few loose ends that had irked me a little (e.g. limit switch fixing holes). Unfortunately I had no access to the original design files so had to make my own using OpenSCAD.

Design basics

My design is not as pretty as the originals, as I was too lazy to design the nice curves and neat linear bearing supports (mine are fixed with cable ties). The pieces are mostly straight-edged, albeit with nice curved corners.

The minimum requirements to implement the new bearing setup are: XY_carriage_base, XY_carriage_top, Y_back, Y_front, and base_slide. I used the original X-axis motor mounts and Z-carrier, and designed my own M3 knob to hold the pen (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2530144).

I have included a few extras, e.g. a servo arm that almost certainly will need to be modified to your own needs, as it was designed for my unbranded/unlabelled 9g servo. Note that it's almost impossible to print good servo shaft splines with an 0.4 nozzle, and in the end I modified a normal servo arm.

I have also included a source file for X-axis motor mounts, although I didn't use them myself - the originals are perfectly fit for purpose, so my file is only offered in case you wish to modify things in that area.

There is a file called support_tube.scad that generates a socket that can be glued to the existing X-axis motor mount on whichever side you prefer. This is used to locate the cable support that comes from the XY carriage. The Y-front OpenSCAD file gives an option whether or not to generate a support tube as part of the compilation (hopefully clear in the SCAD file).

Common definitions file

Note that almost all of the SCAD design files require the dimensions.scad file in the same directory to compile correctly. This file defines dimensions common to many parts, and also contains a number of modules used throughout the design.

Test files

There are 2 test files: horizontal_test_piece.scad and vertical_test_piece.scad, which allow you adjust values in the common file dimensions.scad without wasting too much plastic in the process. These cover things like hole diameters, the linear bearing locating grooves, captive nut holes and cable tie holes (I used 2.5mm x 100mm ties). The horizontal test piece is probably the most important one to get right.

The intention is that if you can get these pieces to print with all the dimensions correct for your components then all the other pieces will also be correct. Hopefully.

Alternative bearings

Flanged bearings: F604ZZ (qty. 10)
The bearings in the X carriage were mounted using M4 socket cap-head bolts - the screw heads have to be either narrow (like mine) or very flat, as the clearance between the screw head and the Y-axis rods is very small.

The assembly sequence for the XY-carriage was: M4 screw with threaded part pointing downwards, M4 washer, bearing with flange upwards, M4 washer, bearing with flange downwards, M4 washer, hole in X-carriage body, M4 washer, M4 Nylok nut.

A similar sequence was followed in the Y-axis back piece: M4 screw with threaded part pointing upwards, M4 washer, through first hole of the Y-axis back piece, M4 washer, bearing with flange downwards, M4 washer, bearing with flange upwards, M4 washer, through second hole of the Y-axis back piece, and into the M4 captive nut.

Printer:

G&C CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

33%

Notes:

Mine was printed using PLA at 0.2mm, with the exception of the base_slide, which I printed at 0.1mm for finer detail.
Support was "as necessary" - most parts don't require it, but things like the base_slide will need it.

title: StartUp3D delta printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Start-Up 3D delta printer is a small dimension delta 3D printer designed for desktop use and intended for hobbyist without previous experience with 3D printing. The print volume is currently only 160mm circle diameter, 150mm height of the object (should be extended to 160x160 mm) with unheated glass bed (currently used a glass bed with tiny layer of a dry glue for multiple prints without maintenance). Hotend E3D V6 clone with bowden extruder for 1.75mm PLA filament. Using NEMA17 stepper motors, Arduino Mega 2560 with Ramps 1.4 and A4988 StepStick stepper drivers as cheapest possible alternative. Construction is made of 30x30mm alu profiles connected by printed PLA parts. 8 mm smooth rods with bearings (LM8UU) are used with carbon rods (200 mm length) and traxxas joins for effector motion. The printer is still in development stage but also ready to use. There is used Raspberry Pi 3 instead of display and SD card connected to Arduino board. But of course can be used with this option witouth Raspberry Pi. Timing belt GT2 - pulleys 20 teeth are used. Printer size 320mm, height 520mm + spool of PLA on the top. Printer price is under 200 €.

You can see more details also on the reprap.org comunity:
http://reprap.org/wiki/Startup3D

Send me a message in case you would like to develope this printer and would need to get also the original files created in Fusion360.

Seed Plate for Earthway 1001B seeder. (Carrots)

This seed plate i made for carrots, although it can be used for other small seeds.

It has a 3 Inch spacing which plants closer together then the plate that comes with the Seeder.

The plate has no inside curvature to help the seed drop into the hole. It also has no angle on the tab to help the seed drop in. I made it flat, for 2 reasons. One- Easy manufacture and 2- because it is easily customisable with a knife, file, etc, for fine tuning. For carrots it works ok with no real alterations.
When the seeder is stationary it will pick up more then one seed, however when being pushed, with a lot of movement, it seems to just pick up and deliver just one seed. However it's hard to tell when its being pushed through the dirt.

You can easily join the hub to the outer edge and print as one. Sketchup file included.
The press fit works well. There should not be any stress on the plate to make it slip.
Printed in PLA and there seems to be no stress or reason for the printed plate to break.

Let me know if you try it. Happy planting!

Blank Split seed Plate https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2601068
Blank Seed Plate https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2594042

This shelf support is designed for shelves that are at least 25cm deep. The end connection part has to be printed two times. Holes for screws to attach the support to the wall and the shelf are incuded.

The connecting parts are designed for rods with a diameter of 6mm. I used aluminium tube, but you can use anything you want including steel or wood. It could be that the holes are a little tight in which case you can drill them out a little bit.

Lengths of the rods:
[4x] 201mm
[2x] 143mm
[2x] 78mm

Hardware required:
[4x] 10mm (or longer) m4 bolts
[4x] m4 nuts
[10x] 4mm diameter countersunk screws

In the pictures you can find the assembly process (it is not too hard).

I would love to see anyone making these! If you have any problems or suggestions, please let me know in the comments. Good luck making!

author: RepRap_projects

title: Easy exchange filament extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For a new printer I needed an extruder setup.

Because I print with ABS a lot this one is designed to do just that (but it also works with other filaments).
With ABS printing you do not want to have airflow passing the printed parts.
Therefor the air is inhaled from above. Then passed through to the Hot-end and then back out at the top. The same airflow construction is also made for de motor. This way the printed part never gets cooled by these 2 fans. For the dimensions of these snail house fans, see picture.

Also I wanted an extruder on which changing filament is easy. On most extruders you can’t see the filament wire and that can make it hard to change filament. If you run out of filament due the print, you are in big trouble. Therefor I made this one in such a way that you can always see the filament wire.

Because I have 3 different sizes of Filament (1.75mm, 2.85mm & 3mm) this extruder can use them all.
To do this I have made an exchangeable filament wire guide. For the 1.75 mm filament I also need to put in a Teflon tube because the hot-end is made for 3mm wire. (I can recommend the Teflon tube anyways because the filament go’s in much smoother). The filament guide is also adjustable so you can gide you filament perfectly. In the photos you do not see this guide because that is still the proto type. On that model the 3mm gide is fixed to the body. Not so smart, because you can’t adjust anything anymore. Also I broke it :-) . As a lose part you can just print it out again. The guide is mounted using a washer, M3 nut and 10mm bolt.

The little filament driver (11mm diameter) is mounted on an M8x50mm bolt I had lying around. On the lathe I turned the end of this M8 bolt down to 5mm so the driver can be mounted on it. See pictures.

The Hot-end is a cheap Chinese one I do not even know the name of, but it works very good. For the dimensions of this Hot-end see pictures.

The stepper motor is a Nema 17 x 47mm. I recommend a strong motor for this if you want to use 2.85 & 3mm filament wire. In the picture you see a 42BYGHW811, but I use an SL42S247A at the moment (a bit more torque). As a driver I still use an A9844 with heavy cooling and heat sink.

For the main body I had to add support material. See picture about the removal of the support material. All other parts can be printed without support. I have printed all parts in PET-G 0.2mm resolution and a 0.4 nozzle

You also need:
3x bearing 608z
1x 11mm driver
1X M8 x 50mm bolt or something similar
1x hot-end
2x snail house fan
1X spring (optional, depending on filament material)
1X nema 17 stepper
1x kapton tape
12X M3 nut
4X M3 x6mm bolt
9X M3 x 10 mm bolt
3X M3 x20mm bolt
9X M3 washer (optional)
1X M3 big washer for filament guide
8X M4 nut
5X M4 x20mm bolt
1X M4 x40mm bolt
5X M4 washer (optional)

After assembly it is wise to put katon tape on the bottom to protect the plastic from all the heat.
This way the plastic holds longer

comments.text: how do we wire the fans to get power? are there pins on the board that allow them to get power from the device?
comments.author: Cyberstar254

comments.text: Yes, in main board you can use any 12v pin that receives power from power supply, but I just connected both two fans to power supply directly, which I consider is clearer
comments.author: Cyberstar254

comments.text: Ok, how do I connect then to the power supply without shorting something?
comments.author: Nitemare

comments.text: Red cables from fan to any free (or not free) +V screw in power supply and black cables from fan to any free (or not free) -V (COM) screw, as seen in attached picture. You can connect both two red wires from fans to a single +V output and same for both two black cables connected to a single -V (COM) output.
comments.author: Cyberstar254

comments.text: does it matter which terminal it is? or are they all one voltage?
comments.author: Nitemare

comments.text: Same voltage for all outputs, 12v

author: ce77dd

description.text:
Background

Like most people, I have dozens of plug-in power supplies (a.k.a. "wall warts") to drive all of my gadgets. Each of them comes with a long lead that gets into a knot and tangles with the wires from everything else in the drawer. I designed this thing to keep the wires tidy - simple as that.

It was originally designed for the standard UK plug pins, but I have attempted to make it suitable for EU and US plugs - I have successfully tried an EU plug, but could only design the US one 'to the specification'. It needs to be tried with a real plug!

The SCAD files

The main file is called wall_wart_cable_tidy.scad. This defines the basic reel, and positions the set of holes for the chosen plug.

The plug layout and spacings are defined in plug_layouts.scad. Each definition is called by the main file as appropriate. This file needs to be in the same directory as the other files when printing a reel, or testing a layout.

New plug layouts are tested using plug_test.scad. New plug definitions are first tested with this file, to minimise plastic waste. Once a new plug pin layout is correct it can be called from the main SCAD file and fitted to the basic spool shape.

Further development

I doubt that I will develop this design further, although I will amend the files if someone tells me that the EU or US files are wrong - please let me know in the comments. However, if you want to modify the design for other plugs then please do so, and publish a remix. I welcome all development and would like to see how people get on.

Updates

Australian 3-pin plug now added - many thanks to gaehl for his help in testing the plug layout.

Notes:

Supports are essential - set them up as you normally would, with the aim of easy removal.
Otherwise, use your favourite filament material, resolution and infill value (I used PLA, 0.2 and 30%).

title: Clips for TV table with 16mm legs - print in NYLON

description.text:
These are clips for the smaller tables with folding legs (TV dining tables etc.). They are meant to be attached with rivets. You could use other hardware but then your tabletop wont be flush. Most of these tables have a cheap vinyl upholstery on the top that can be easily lifted up after removing half of the staples (unless you are just replacing it then remove all of them). Sometimes there is some kind of metal or plastic edge holding the stapled material down but if you can get it off without breaking it you can reuse it to make a new piece of upholstery look factory installed.

Recommend printing in Nylon as the nature of a clip is to flex a lot and even ABS will probably break on you. Which if you are upholstering over your rivets would be very frustrating. I can tell you from experience.

I used Taulman 910 because its the only Nylon I had, worked great. Still holding up.

Printer:

Anet A8 Heavy mods

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed at 252 with 70c bed (I have a stacked bed of aluminum,silicon,glass,PEI so my setting is probably higher than you want it) using Filabot Taulman 910. Good squish on first layer and 30mm/sec with abs retract settings and a .4 nozzle saw flawless results. There werent even any boogers in the holes!

Printed on an Anet A8 - see my makes for mods
If you need one here's the link
https://www.gearbest.com/3d-printers-3d-printer-kits/pp_343643.html?lkid=11159199

author: FluxAxiom

title: Remix of CR10 Leveling Knob by Oggie
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Edit: 12.02.18
The new version is perfect. Finally.
Just made some and put them on. They fit just right and tight.
I suggest using at least five top layers so the letters are clearer.
Did mine at 0.16, 203C, 62C bed, around 50-55 speed, 20 %infill. Supports are not necessary, but if you get some small stringing i suggest cutting it away with a scalpel which gives nicer edges.

use Tacblades easy leveling:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gkZUAyTxU1Q

Find Tacblades here on thingiverse for other good mods too.

Edit: 10.01.18 Just uploaded a new version. The previous one had a weird problem (what a surprise...) that was undetected by meshmixer and ideamaker fixing options. It looked ok but it would print badly. This new version is fixed and it prints right.

After a long, tortuous and titanic struggle i finally managed to remix this knob so it fits 17.5mm leveling wheels on my CR10.

This included a lightning storm power failure just as i finished the new improved model in Fusion and tried to save it. And then when i did it again, just before saving, Fusion crashed again... And that was just in one evening.

Now, the new parametric model adjustments have been made and it is ready. Thanks to Oggie.

If the dimension dont fit your wheels you can adjust them in your slicer, but be sure not to make the overall diameter reach 78mm because that will make it scrape against the printer gantry with the two knobs in the back. Or you can download the original Oggie knob.

I just changed the visual design of the center a little bit, so its clearer its a remix and made the whole thing a bit thicker, more or less just mucking around at the end.

Print the Omnimac´s top (Remix Source) to complete it.

title: Battle Fleet Gothic Scale Gladius Frigate Proxy

description.text:
A Gladius Frigate proxy for Battlefleet Gothic.

Inspired by the most excellent series of BFG models by Mkhand_Industries i am working on a project that required this particular ship variation and being suitable motivated for a change decided to bash one together. A couple of small snippets (turrets, bridge and guns from memory) were traced from Mkhand's frigate models https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2594031.

This particular model is meant to print at a similar scale to (for use with) these models. In the official gw pics the gladius frigate looks slightly larger than i.e. a sword frigate. Similarly this model is intended to be that tiny bit larger. Reminds me of a mini strike cruiser.

The model is intended to print as a single/full item. i've had good results with Mkhand's models printing the single piece (full) model, and so i've not broken this one down into parts. managed to get netfabb to play again, yhay. No glue required.

title: SparkFun AVR Programmer Housing w/ Light Pipes

description.text:
I wish I would have looked on Thingiverse prior to designing this, their are already a bunch of great designs available for the Sparkfun Programmer!

I have a SparkFun AVR programmer that I take back and forth to work and I always worry it is going to get broken. That inspired me to make this compact protective housing.

Light pipes are used next to the USB connector but not mandatory. You can still see the light if you have open holes. If you are not familiar with light pipes, they are these glorious little things that capture and redirect light. They are cheap too.

Link to Programmer: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9825

Link to Light Pipes: https://www.digikey.com/short/qt8z9c - There are a TON of options, be creative. Just make sure the lens size is 3mm.

2 Screws: Any simple Flat #3 or #4 screws will work.

This thing is a derivate from the great Sim City 200 Tabletop Play Set by Skimbal. It uses the capitol in a much larger scale filled with an RGB-Light, so the whole thing can be used as an ambient light.
UPDATE 10.07.2012: I've added the floor, which fits exactly into the mainpart and solves as a stand for the embedded LED-controller. I'll upload a picture of it as soon as possible (currently I'm printing the second house). I've also added a "Roof with dome", where both parts are combined and where the dome is hollow however.
I simply took the capitol from his collection, scaled it up to 300%, printed it hollow and filled it with an LED-light-system. This thing describes how I achieved it.

The three biggest problems I faced have been:
  • getting such a big thing printed without any displacement
  • print it with as little filament as possible
  • print it hollow, so that it can be filled with a lamp
    • To solve problem 1 I first needed to find out that I have that problem. ;) I made some test prints to solve problems 2 and 3 and realized, that at some point I had misalignments (aka missing steps) which lead to a failed print. I never realized this before as I only printed parts that have been quite small (2 to 3 hours). I found out, that my printer (orca .4) seems to loose steps when the y-axis has to change direction very quickly. So I simply reduced the speed from 60 to 40mm/s which helped fixing this issue. Nevertheless I have to check why this happens, as the printer itself normaly is capable of going with 60-80mm/s without problems. Problems 2 and 3 have been quite interesting, too. At first I tried to print the capitol with 0 infill, 4 perimeters and support material. But I haven't been able to slice the whole thing with slic3er and so did it with skeinforge. But the support material needed has been very much - much more than the building itself would need. This is simply because the roof needs support from below.
    So I thought about slicing the building into pieces (mainpart, roof, dome) but didn' find a good way to do this and tried it with different CAD- and STL-tools. At the end the best way of doing this was to use Netfabb Basic (free!) to slice it at a specific layer and export the parts as stl again. Then I imported the mainpart in OpenSCAD and removed that much infill, that only the walls remained. That helped me printing it with very little filament and being hollow. Nevertheless, the mainpart, the roof and the dome took about 24 hours to print all together. And I didn't count those plenty test prints I've needed... Another interesting point I've learned during this project is how to stop and resume a print (if you need to leave or want to got to sleep). I learned about the command M114. If you hit "pause" in pronterface simply send this command to the printer beforce disconnecting. This gets you the current position of the printer, so you can get the current Z-height. Then you simply need to find the G-Code line where it says something like "G1 Z2.200", where "2.200" is the height you got from the command. Remove anything before that line (except your start-code). Also remove the G28 (home all axis) and instead insert the command "G92 Z2.000" just before the "G1"-line. Set this line to the value "current-layer-height - layer-thickness" (in my case the layer thickness has been 0.2mm). This makes the printer believe that it is at that height. If you resume a print and leave the axis as they currently are than this is logically true. But this process can be used to cutout pieces of your gcode and just print a part of it starting at a specific layer. For the lights I bought a RGB controller with RF remote, that is capable of controlling some LEDs on a RGB-LED-strip. I bought these from the german supplier Conrad:
    http://www.conrad.de/ce/de/product/190487/EFFEKTGENERATOR-FUeR-RGB-LED-LEISTEN-RF/SHOP_AREA_17357&promotionareaSearchDetail=005
    http://www.conrad.de/ce/de/product/182002/LED-STREIFEN-150LEDS-5M-12V-RGB-CA/SHOP_AREA_26449&promotionareaSearchDetail=005 The fading between the colors is fantastic and you can choose between different modes with the remote. I like it. ;) For the print itself I used the "Crystal clear"-filament from Faberdashery:
    http://www.faberdashery.co.uk/products-page/print-materials/crystal-clear/
    They have very good PLA and sell by the meter! I hope I could give others some idea on what to do with their printer. If you have any question, simply ask and I'll see if I can answer it. ;)

title: MakerGear M2 V4 extruder and dual fan kit

description.text:
I have found improved extruders and I've found improved fan assemblies, but not a solid combo unit for the MakerGear M2 with V4 hotend. This also allows you to upgrade the fans to 40mm Noctua units. www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009NQLT0M/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
This runs quiet, allows for easy assembly, gives plenty of clearance over the bed with the angled fan unit, and prints with minimal supports.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

A raft is useful on the fan portion due to the tall supports needed for the mounting plate area. I had the best luck printing with PETG, but also worked with in ABS and PLA.

Why it's worth printing

The stock fans are loud and inefficient. Noctua fans are quiet and work very well. The stock extruder doesn't hold things together as well as it could. The tapered hot end fan provides direct cooling where it's needed, so you can use a smaller fan at a lower speed.

This is the updated design of the filament holder
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2568123
with added friction - now the spool will not unwind randomly which may cause problem during the printing.

I used 0.1mm thin metal sheet (from stencils) glued with double adhesive to one of the bearing holders. Four pieces of felt were attached with double adhesive to the arms of the friction plate (friction wheel). The arms holding the felt have spring properties (they are like leafs) and by using the correct washer (friction spacer) as spacer between friction wheel and the bearing we can adjust the friction force.

Now the Filament holder has both smooth movement and controlled friction - works like charm. It's designed for MakerBot Replicator2 but could be used for any other 3D printer by changing the attachment plate.

OpenForge
=========
Crenelated corner tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles. Can be stacked on Stone Corner Tiles or Stone Wall Tiles with Pillars to create defensive walls.
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Painting

Painting was done in 5 layers.
  • Paint whole piece in black
  • Heavily dry brush with a dark grey
  • pick at least one other color (that could be stone) and paint some random stones, front and back.
  • dry brush with grey mixed with a little olive
  • lightly dry brush with a light grey, focusing most heavily on edges

comments.author: electricmonk9

comments.text: I either print in black or natural.  If I pint in natural, I give it a black coat.  I then do a heavy dry brush with a dark grey, trying to let some of the black show throgh.  I pick a number of stones to paint with an olive-brown.  Next I dry brush with a light olive.  Finally I dry brush with a light grey, being sure to wipe off with my fingers anything I can that gets on the brown stones.

First item to upload, and it's a simple one. Part of my 40K terrain is to make pipes come into storage containers (painted soda cans).
However, Soda Cans are circular, whilst the end of a straw is straight. This often ends up with a big, messy dollop of hot glue.

This item is a very simple box, one side is curved to fit a regular 330ml soda can perfectly, the other has a hole to slide a straw into.

I designed it in Fusion 360. I've printed it on a Monoprice Mini without any issues.

NOTE: Despite there being a "standard" straw diameter, I did find some variety. I have added the original fusion360 file here so that you can modify the diameter if needed.

I wanted to upgrade the stand for my millennium 3D chess set. its a fun extension of Chess!
These are simple legs to support the plexi/tempered glass levels; the corner slot is high enough that you can double-up materials if wanted/needed.

Rules for game play are here

Leg/Post deisng

I designed this to be super simple, all the legs are identical and join so the brick pattern will always continue. This enables setup to go quick since the order doesn't matter AND if a leg breaks you just have to print a new leg NOT a new set.
You'll need (8) ChessSupports
You'll need (4) 3D_Cap

The Hell Skull on the cap is not my design, but found via the link here on thingiverse. I had to make alterations; however the start point was from another contributor.

Board design

My boards are made with tempered glass where the black squares were ground into the glass then the whole board sealed with a clear coat ... there is a plan for these to be replaced with 2 plexi glass levels with vinyl overlays and level 1 to become a laser engraved tile ... I'll upload pics once upgrade is complete.

On the photo I still use old version of wood hinge.

2 screws (10 mm) - my screw head additional 2,5mm but if your will be longer or shorter, you can use washers to align it with magnets

Fill free to remix, edit and whatever.

So now you can use large heads on this thingi but flipping them around. Hope its useful. :)

title: MendelMax adjustable Z axis end stop

description.text:
The end stop for the Z axis that came with my MendelMax is only adjustable by sliding it up and down the 8mm rod, not very practical, so I made one that can be tuned by turning a wheel.
It uses two M3 x 8mm socket head screws for the clamp and a 20mm to adjust the height. The spring is optional.
The wheel screw needs to be fixed in place with glue so it won't slip. I included the DesignSpark Mechanical file so anyone can modify it if they wish to. The M3 screw has a 0.5mm thread, the adjustment wheel has 10 gradations, so each step moves the end stop by 0.05mm

comments.text: I just printed one of these and it works great - thank you for sharing!  For the spring, I just removed one from a ball-point pen :).  There was one minor modification I had to make though   For some reason, the clamp was too loose with my 8mm rods.  I placed a few layers of tape inside the clamping surfaces to thicken them, and now it seems to be a bit better.
comments.author: Gigahurtz

comments.text: I don't remember, but it's quite possible that there's a "fudge factor" in the 8mm clamp to accommodate what Slic3r was outputting for me.
comments.author: Gigahurtz

comments.text: The first one I made was in PLA and had no cracking problems, maybe the difference is that I didn't tighten it a lot, just enough to stay in place and allow me to slide it up and down whenever I changed the print bed from not heated to heated (the heated bed was taller than the screw on the clamp allowed for adjustment)
comments.author: Gigahurtz

These protect your arm ends and front and back - and are sacrificial to protect your frame from delaminating or splintering - so print a few and save your frame.

author: MortalTombat

description.text: I used to use a bendy desk lamp to light up the print bed but it didn't work too well so I bought a bunch of cheap USB LED strips from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00198L9RA/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00) and then designed this mount to attach to the Y rods on my Prusa. It lights up the bed pretty well with nice clean light.

1) Buy some of these: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00198L9RA/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00
2) Print one mount and two clips for each LED strip you want to install.
3) Slide the clips onto the LED strip.
4) Insert the clips into the mount.
5) Snap the mount onto your Y rods using a twisting action.

description.text:
This is a lavish looking filament spool holder for up to two rolls of filament.

Take two ca. 20 centimeter smooth rods (8mm) and 13x22 cm base plate (I used a 18mm thick MDF-plate, which gives a solid stand).

The top part is easy to take off, to change the rolls. The feet fit very tightly, so the rods don't fall out.

Tip: You can use leftovers from cutting smooth rods when building a 3D-printer, as the exact height doesn't actually matter and its a shame to throw them away.

EDIT: PLA is totally fine for this, no need start a hassel with ABS oder PETG etc.

title: Smartrap Mini - Improvements in the X and Y axis

description.text:
Based on the Smartrap Mini from Smartfriendz project.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:177256. The project intends to introduce a number of improvements to the movement of the X and Y axes to make it smoother and more precise. These improvements do not require modifications to the original design of the pieces of the printer, as it is only necessary to make specific holes to accommodate the screws that hold the bearings acting as tensors. The whole movement is performed through a toothed pulley that pulls a strap of a GT2 type, held to the ends with flanges. Furthermore, housings for endstop (http://piol.in/1fYvqM5) nicely fitting with the aesthetics of the original design are added. To simplifying the behavior of the printer, the system of self- calibration of the Z axis has been changed with a simpler system of regulation based on a screw. Finally, two anchors have been added to hold the printer to the underlying wooden platform.
  • Español
    • Basado en el proyecto Smartrap Mini de Smartfriendz.
    (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:177256) Se trata de introducir una serie de mejoras para el movimiento de los ejes X e Y, que lo hagan más suave y preciso. Estas mejoras no precisan de modificaciones en el diseño original de las piezas que conforman la impresora y tan solo es necesario realizar unos agujeros para alojar los tornillos que sujetan los rodamientos que hacen de tensor. Todo el movimiento se realiza a través de una polea dentada que tracciona una correa de tipo GT2, sujeta a los extremos con bridas. Además, se añaden unos alojamientos para los endstop (http://piol.in/1fYvqM5) que encajan perfectamente con la estética del diseño original. Por simplificar el comportamiento de la impresora, se ha cambiado el sistema de auto-calibración del eje Z, por uno más simple, basado en un tornillo que regula la altura. Por último, se han añadido dos anclajes para sujetar el conjunto a la madera que sirve de base a la impresora.

comments.author: fbuenonet

comments.text:
Sir, I changed the values of these...
const bool X_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = true;
const bool Y_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = true;
const bool Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = true;
const bool X_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false;
const bool Y_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false;
const bool Z_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false;
and I got the correct movement but it doesn't stop when it hit the endstop.
Is this the line that I I have to change the value also, #if X_HOME_DIR == -1?
I'm sorry for the questions.
comments.author: gab0natchi

comments.text:
What you have to do is try to see if it works as you want endstop. If not, change the value of the corresponding variable. Ie, if it is true, put in false and if false change it to true.
The value of the variable must be X_HOME_DIR to -1 if you want the endstop it acts when the X axis approaches the minimum. That is X = 0. If you want to score the maximum value, the X_HOME_DIR variable must have the value 1.
comments.author: gab0natchi

comments.text: Sir, did you move the x endstop to the back? If I do that, do I have to modify something on the firmware configuration?
comments.author: gab0natchi

comments.text:
If now the X-endstop is to indicate the X = 0 position and you want to indicate the maximum position of the X axis, you have to change the logic of X_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING X_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING variables and (if you have them to true, you must put in false or vice versa) and put the value 1 X_HOME_DIR
If, however, what you want is that when the hotend approaches to block the Z axis goes to its maximum position X, then you have to change the logic of INVERT_X_DIR variable (reverse the polarity of the wires of the motor axis X is also true).
comments.author: gab0natchi

comments.text: si el sueño me lo permite, esta noche empiezo a imprimir las piezas!
comments.author: fbuenonet

comments.text: acabo de revisar las piezas, puede ser que falten las piezas donde se montan los rodamientos?
comments.author: nic0laz

comments.text:
No. Es que no necesita ninguna pieza. Lo que he hecho es agujeros de 3mm en los que pongo los tornillos M3 x 25. Con una tuerca sujeto el tornillo a las piezas de plástico y añado varias arandelas hasta que los rodamientos quedan centrados con la correa. Luego pongo una tuerca autoblocante para regular la presión sobe el rodamiento y que le permita girar libremente y el montaje está hecho.
Por supuesto que se podrían hacer unos ejes e imprimirlos junto a las piezas lm8_holder que sujetan los rodamientos lineales o, por lo menos, los agujeros para que salgan ya impresos, pero haciéndolo de esta forma es perfectamente funcional y queda bien.
Solo tienes que tener en cuenta que el tornillo que va junto al final de carrera del eje X, cae sobre el motor, por lo que tendrás que hacer un avellanado en la pieza plate_X, por la parte de abajo, para que la cabeza del tornillo quede enrasada con la pieza de plástico y no tope con el motor.

description.text:
A little project I made for a school fundraiser. The spinners are a bit too big for smaller kids to "pinch hold" while spinning, and the lack of significant weight (together with high-drag shapes) means spin times are unimpressive, but hopefully the cute look still makes them a fair mini-gift. Painting small color details with enamel modelling paint adds a finished touch.

Designed to print with 0.25mm layers. Other thicknesses won't fit together quite so well. Also, I recommend printing at 100% infill to maximize the weight. You may need to scale up or down 1% or so to fit your bearings, depending on your printer's tolerance.

If you print parts in white, green, and red plastic, I reckon there are 8100 possible combinations.

Uses standard 608 ball bearings.

Caps are remixed from the excellent ones in 2ROBOTGUY's Tri Fidget Spinner Toy, here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1802260

BTW, anyone interested in producing these commercially, I'm open to licensing.

Hi guys,
since my filament didn't come in a spool and I couldn't find a spool that seemed to satisfy my needs, I decided to design my own: The filament holder is a derivative from this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16267 (filament_guide_v4) This is my first entry, I hope you like it :)

Just clip in the holder between the two threaded rods, the nuts should be M8 to fit into the holes, screw in another M8 threaded rod (cut to the desired length, mine are about 20cm which the holder can easily hold, not sure about lengthier spools)
then assemble the spool itself: you will need the spool 2x, press in the two 608ZZ bearings, cut M6 threaded rods to the desired length (again mine are ~20cm) and tighten the M6 nuts (use washers in between!)
on the top of the M8 threaded rod just counterlock 2 nuts so the spool stays in place
Then just roll the filament onto the spool! I printed 2 spools which I use for different colors or materials, but having to also simplifies rolling the filament onto the second spool! The holes in the spool are for adjusting the spool diameter and as a starting point for the filament! BOM:
Printed:
2x Spool.stl
1x Spoolholder.stl Hardware:
1x M8 threaded rod (~20-30cm)
3x M6 threaded rod (~20-30cm)
12x M6 nuts
12x M6 washers
4x M8 nut
a few M8 washers (to space the spool away from obstacles(z-motors))
2x 608ZZ bearing
  • some PLA or ABS

Just a quick little design for a project/ gift for my dad.

-You'll need to print 2 bases (the rings) to close around the body (the G)

-You'll need 4 pegs to hold the bases together

-There's a margin of error of .5 mm between the holes in the base and the pegs, so it can be slightly loose so be aware of that.

-The part should be 1 to 1 in cms and is roughly 6 cms tall by 8 cms wide.

-If any scale is wrong with the .stl files do let me know as it's the first design, so errors are expected.

-Thank you!
